messages.content:
Day 1 - Getting set up

Enjoyed all the intro calls. I am going to spend the rest of the day preparing for the coming days and weeks.

  • Rebuild my personal website in Hugo this afternoon so I can have a space to publish easily
    • Use tailwind with a theme so I don't waste time on the UI bits
  • Get obsidian up to date so I can use the new interactive canvas to organize my knowledge
    • Ties back into the Hugo powered website so I can do "digital gardening"
  • Record a vlog
  • (maybe tomorrow) Post somewhere about interest in smallish (2 day?) project(s) this week to build inertia
    • Bookworm
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
Day 2 - No one is surprised I didn't get anything done :see_no_evil:

Had an absolutely fantastic day talking to folks. This is what I am here for!

Current thoughts:

  • My mental health through RC is top priority
    • No negative self talk for not accomplishing programming tasks as long as I have been productive in some way
      • This is not an excuse to be undisciplined
    • Embrace JOMO. The Joy Of Missing Out. There is a lot going on and no way I can participate in all of the things that interest me. Good!
  • Everyone here is _fantastic_. I am sure it helps that we largely self selected to participate.
  • For a second day this is going exactly as I imagined it would

For actually getting things done:

  • Talk less, show more
  • Stick to the plan from D1 and finish building out my online space to organize and share information
  • Daily checkins are the minimum amount of comms for me so might make more use of #consciousness

TODO:

  • Finish website in Hugo + Tailwind
  • Record vlog (already missed one day)
  • Play some more with Mastermind in Go with unit tests
  • [Friday] Obsidian all up to date (missing all RC info still)
  • [Next Week] Project plan(s) written with some time commitments
    • Bookworm
    • Raytracer
    • All info for flow based programming
    • Schedule podcast interviews (@-me if you wanna talk about _anything_ :sunglasses: )
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
Day 3 - Doing things slower than I want

Another day I enjoyed meeting folks and learning more about what others are working on! There is a lot of content in here because I am pushing on too many things right now. Feeling good about accomplishing things mentioned yesterday.

Fully leaned into JOMO this afternoon.

  • Obsidian is updated and some RC info has made it in just not organized
  • Broke my rules yesterday and worked super late but made some progress on my site
    • Hugo is causing me some minor issues in the local dev server with pages not showing up
    • Tailwind is going to require alpine js which is easy enough but just another small bump in the road
    • Might present next week on why I like Hugo's patterns / methodologies...
  • Created #visual programming to get some conversations out in the open. Come join us if you are interested.
  • Streamed an ~hour on twitch https://www.twitch.tv/videos/1698701338
    • show more talk less
    • love the performative side but embarrased how bad my Go muscle memory / tacit knowledge is with only a few months away
    • wasted a bunch of time on setup and didn't get to a fulling working fix so maybe @Anonymous User will pair with me again only this time in Go! and help me understand what I am missing when checking for multiple colors :sweat_smile:

:hammer_and_wrench: Projects keep swirling in my head and slowing shaping up even if interest / prioritization is not clear yet I definitely want to do things with visual feedback

  • raytracer
  • researching flow based programming from first principles
    • leading to a visual represenation of a subset of HCL
    • parse HCL to AST or such, transform to boxes and arrows and vice versa
  • chatting with John about creating an audiogram generator
    • https://github.com/nypublicradio/audiogram exists but is hard to get to work on windows for me
  • still thinking about a creative endeavor mentioned on my application of a tool to easily create lego style instructions for minecraft builds

Random: interesting thing shared with me today... https://theherosjournal.co/
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
Day 4 - Where did the week go?

Overall it has been a fantastic week but I am nowhere near where I need to be.
Certainly not where I want to be, either, but getting my personal site fixedup
is holding up being able to free my mind. This weekend it has to be finished
so I can get my podcast edited and the first episode with show notes published.

  • Mostly just chats and tinkering today
    • Scheduled a lean coffee to talk knowledge management next wednesday
    • Thoroughly enjoyed going to the feelings checkin. Glad I'm not alone :people_hugging:
    • Enjoyed the social gaming this evening
  • Big thanks to folks helping out today...
    • @Anonymous User for helping collect recipes!
    • @Anonymous User for talking audiogram things
    • @Anonymous User for pairing on hugo issues and setting up pairing time for next week
  • :movie_theater: streamed again for ~30 minutes strugging through Hugo
    • at least I caught the issue so it can be witnessed happening :sweat_smile:
    • covers using https://asdf-vm.com/ which I mentioned in another thread so if you've never seen asdf used check it out!

I am not in the pit of despair yet but I do hate I'm going to have to work tonight and tomorrow on Hugo stuff when I thought it would be super simple to throw together. That's how it goes!
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
Day 5 - Thinking about balancing RC and responsibilities

First it's important to call out my feels. And they are: Feels Goodman.

image.png

I am thinking a LOT about Ira Glass and his talk about "The Gap"

  • Animated / edited concise version: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ieEQ21mCOJA

That relates to the story from "Art & Fear" where a class was split into being graded on quantity vs quality and the quality was higher in the group focused on quantity. I am sure I am on the correct path to recovery from my burn out and now I am almost scared to commit to just doing the work. Like my brain has some finite amount of cycles and I am going to exhaust them. It is a very unusual and somewhat unsettling idea (surely without merit).

Anyway, I ended up working and playing over the weekend and got a couple twitch streams in:

  • Continuing tinkering with Hugo & Tailwind
  • Replaying The Beginners Guide and talking about all the feels that it invoked in me

Successes:

  • Great chats with folks
  • Signed up to present my favorite tools on Friyay
  • Hugo is now rendering all the site content
  • Microfeed setup was a breeze and seems to work great
  • Streaming is getting incrementally better each time (but I still keep making mistakes as expected)
  • Enjoyed the volitional muscle exercise today
    • 26 ideas
    • Paid attention to how I felt describing them
    • Narrowed down to a top 10 easily which had 2 common themes
      • Visual / graphics
      • Extrensic motivation to have something to show off
        • Maybe a bit external validation, too... (relevant to The Beginners Guide)

Challenges:

  • Missed the meeting I scheduled like a fool. Learned an important lesson about the RC <-> gcal syncing.
  • Balacing life responsibility and keeping a healthy mental attitude about what is reasonable and possible in the time I have.
    • Joined #parenting to see if there were any relevant thoughts around this
    • Watched and thoroughly enjoyed the Bryan Cantrill talk from Monktoberfest
      • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VzdVSMRu16g
  • Shipping my website and feeling OK with it
    • Get OUT of my head. Perfection is the enemy. JUST DO IT.
  • Deciding if I should ask to extend my RC participation from 6 to 12 weeks
    • Real life budget constraints here... potentially need to be doing paid work

This continues to be everything I thought it would be. Tons of fantastic folks doing fascinating work and feeling welcomed and supported to try and fail. Proud of everyone sharing and scared to think about going back to a job where everyone is competing with each other and much less supportive.

Do you like LaCroix?
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
Day 6 - Donuts that you can't eat

donut.gif

Stare in amazement and wonder. BEHOLD the beauty of an ascii donut spinning in my terminal.

On to the checkin...

I feel fantastic. I am enjoying every conversation I have with folks and am looking forward to all the things to come.

:first_place: Accomplishments

  • The SDF donut renderer written in Go made my day (I know you didn't notice)
  • TWO, yes, two THREE! twitch streams. Found some great music, too.
  • :pear: Paired with Zach - we share a lot of the same interests and motivations.
  • Created a simple visualizer for audio in davinici

Things to work on:

  • Finish slides for presentation on Friday
  • Publish Hugo site
  • Redo microfeed on fishtales subdomain
  • Start in on Raytracer
  • Less backseat driving when pairing :grimacing: :disappointed:
  • Commit to some sort of project next week

:calendar: Life outside of RC:

  • No inperson checkins for the next two days
    • Wednesday AFK until the knowledge management event at 3pm and then AFK again afterward to attend All Things Open meetup
    • Thursday AFK until ~3pm ET

What a FANTASTIC Tuesday!
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
Proud of everyone sharing and scared to think about going back to a job where everyone is competing with each other and much less supportive.

this made me fantasize about a world where we could all just band together and build a place and culture where we enjoy working. a girl can dream... sigh
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content: This is what I want to do.... I want to make an employee owned co-op
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content: I have a long internal thread around ... if software is so value (can generate high valuations, high paying jobs), how can I directly engage that? I'm personally debating between doing a (probably ML themed) job search and continuing to learn and grow and starting a company / building a product (trying to benefit directly) -- but it's very related to: how can I work in a culture that works for me, not against me? By building that culture?
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content: I am convinced I am going to have to build it myself
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content: Perma-cultures of one :green_heart:
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
my favorite book in this arena is Reinventing Organizations. It's probably one of my top 5 most important things I've read that I keep very firmly in the altar of my heart. https://www.reinventingorganizations.com/

I think there are a lot of interesting tactical questions like - a consulting / services group vs. finding a compelling product area / vision and diving in.

right now there's exactly one AI company i'm on the fence about applying to, and a lot of really just comes down to "do i really think my own values will be fully expressed there?" (or can I tactically justify the role as an intermediate step -- which I am dubious of, but considering.)

but RO is my favorite thing.
i have lots of favorites
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
That's a strong recommendation. I will read that.

https://corporate-rebels.com/ was recommended to me but I haven't read it yet. I do like the videos and such I saw.
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content: this list of worker owned tech coops might be of interest to anyone thinking of starting one or looking into that model!
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
Days 7 & 8 - I missed the rhythm of RC :rhythm:

I noted on Day 6 I was going to be sparse due to outside commitments so this is a double update.

Wednesday 1/11/23

Had lunch with a friend that works in video games and picked his brain about some things and spent the night at All Things Open Spacewalk meetup in downtown Raleigh.

In between, however, we did the knowledge management lean coffee! I LOVED it! So glad I got to introduce lean coffee to so many new folks and we had a great discussion around knowledge management tools and workflows. I suspect we might do it again...

Thursday 1/12/13

Had to go to a meeting out of town which sucked up my morning and then I decided to go have tea with my mom.

Thought I would be back online in the afternoon but decided to go to my kid's gymnastics class and out to dinner with the fam.

Spending the past two days largely away from the computer doing social things was the right call. Somewhat unexpectedly I _really_ missed the rhythm RC has got me in.

I think this is the first time in a year I have had a _great_ week. Not just OK; thoroughly enjoying every day. Talking with so many fascinating folks.

Tonight / tomorrow morning I have to finish my slides for my presentation on my favorite tools which was spurred by the Hugo work I was doing when RC started.
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
"I think this is the first time in a year I have had a _great_ week."
What a great thing to have had a great week!!
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
Yes, yes.

I am very grateful for RC.
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
Day 9 - Favorite Things :dancing:

Today was a simple day. Tweet out my slides and talk to fellow RC'ers

Huge thanks to @Anonymous User and @Anonymous User for the conversations today.

Thanks to everyone for suffering through my inability to sing but I hoped you found it silly and it made laugh, roll your eyes or BOTH! :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing:

Slides from my presentation are shared from my Google Drive

Tomorrow is going to be more website work and final production work on the podcast intro / outro and getting episode 1 ready for publishing wednesday
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
Day 10 - Weekend + holiday work

I finally hit a stride with Hugo, Tailwind and Alpine and ended up not needing Alpine at all, really.

Content creation has went well but I am missing all kinds of written content so I need to do some digital gardening and dig up old content from old versions of my site and get things published. It's nice to have a workflow emerging and knowing I have a space to dump things.

So to recap:

  • Podcast is publishing via Microfeed on the CloudFlare stack (pages, D1, R2, DNS)
  • Website is published via CloudFlare pages + GitHub
    • Manually building the site locally and jamming it into the poorly named "docs" folder which is a relic of trying to make it work on GitHub.
    • Need to move it all to a new repo and start clean
  • Episode 0 of the podcast is published and live on RSS, YouTube and Spotify
    • Submitted to Apple and Google
  • Episode 1 is rendered with audio-driven effects and I have a workflow for getting future episodes generated
  • :right: All I have to do this week is write up the show notes before 8am Wednesday - content is ready to go live.

:relief: :relieved:

I would say I will lose 90 minutes to the show notes and final prep / push for episode 1 which gives me a ton of time to dig in on something else... which I think will be starting the weekend raytracing walkthrough in earnest and spending more cycles on geometry.

This week is going to be super busy for me. Real life has crept back in and I am going to have to travel on Thursday and Friday but hopefully I will manage to salvage half the day on Friday but likely won't have a written checkin Thursday.

It's gonna be a great week!

images/hlwpjv1y90ZsyRWFDdxEaXDp-ezgif-4-212dcc9592.gif
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
Day 11 - Transitioning to more programming

I am late in my update because I was in bed listening to an audiobook before 8pm ET last night. I was definitely asleep before 9pm. Too many late nights over the weekend caught up to me.

Spend all of Day 11 talking and looking at ray tracing information sources before committing to ray tracing in a weekend.

  • Podcast episode 1 is live and I think folks here would enjoy hearing from Ange
    • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bi6bLSCnjcY&list=PL1lx2vQxCloMJl9mo1UcSTpf8KjLA3ekl&index=2
  • Check out https://www.engine-sim.parts/ for more info on the Engine Simulator (I've mentioned to a few folks already)

I realized I need to do the whole social media cards setup in my site's <head>. Oops :see_no_evil:

:question: Wondering if anyone else currently in this batch is interested in infrastructure automation (cloud orchestration, CDK, terraform, ansible, etc). :cloud: :hammer_and_wrench:
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content: I'm super interested in infrastructure tooling! I don't know how much I can fit in as my batch closes out, but I'm definitely down to chat at least
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
The engine simulator is so cool! And really calming too, having owned an electric car for the past few years I didn't realize how much I missed engine noise. Will have to check out your podcast.

I am casually interested in the cloud stuff. We use terraform at work and I've been trying to get some more insight around it, but haven't found a way to make it fun for myself.
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
Finished listening to the podcast right now; what a great episode, truly loved all the insight and hearing Ange's story :relaxed:
Looking forward to the next ones! :studio_microphone:
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content: I'm looking to work in infrastructure for some reason, so I'm keen to learn more about it, although honestly I don't really have personal projects right now that need much infrastructure
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content: I have some ideas on how to make learning Terraform engaging. I will collect my thoughts and share next week
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
Day 12 - Tracing rays

Seems like I might have a mild cold. Covid tests are negative :fingers_crossed:. Perhaps not enough rest has worn me down. I was in bed at 8pm again so my checkin is lagging to the following morning again.

Today (day 13) I will miss impossible stuff day due to external obligations and I am bummed. I still have an idea about analyzing roads that I have no idea how to accomplish so I might try to make it to maptime (which I was just too tired to attend last night).

:picture: Yesterday I managed to create this masterpiece:

image.png

But that's not good because it should look like the one from the raytracing book

I have not used C++ since ~2000 and I want to write the raytracer in Go so I have most likely screwed something up translating the authors code. I chased my tail for a couple hours getting the background to work correctly due to misinterpreting the c++ semantics and mutating my vec3 struct in Go when it should have been left alone so it might be the same thing causing the sphere to be visualized wrong. I will be back in the swing of things Friday afternoon and will add unit tests around my vec3 implementation to ensure it's core behavior is correct.

The graphics stuff is fun and I am slowly understanding more fundamentals. I am almost caught up enough to get a group together around the geometry parts I am lost on around normals and such.
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
Days 13 - 14 & The Weekend

I ended up missing impossible day on Thursday 1/19 (day 13) and everything on Friday 1/20 (day 14). I really missed getting to read all the updates and see what everyone has been doing... time is slipping through my hands and it's not a good feeling. This offically marks half-way through my batch and I don't have much to show.

I tinkered all weekend on the raytracing work and after chasing my tail for hours today I can finally render something somewhat interesting (as have all those that came before me).

:drum: :drum: :drum:

image.png

My focus this week is going to be on finishing the first part of the raytracing book and then exploring some proceedural coding with wave function collapse (of which I only know what it does but not how to use it or "make it"). So many ideas and interesting things and so little time

I am sick with a cold and not sleeping well and as long as that doesn't take me out I shouldn't be missing any days or activities this week :fingers_crossed:

Also - yesterday - I got a little carried away with my lacroix fandom and made an overlay for OBS / streamlabs :sunglasses: :thumbs_up:

ezgif-3-85a8c69b4f.gif

Hope everyone has a great week! :call_me: :call_me:
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
Day 15 - achoo, cough, cough :sneezing:

Well I didn't really get anything done today other than parallelize my ray tracer.

I bookmarked a few things related to wave function collapse but I just didn't get anything going.

Tomorrow I have to go to the dentist first thing but when I get back I plan to get the dialectrics working in the ray tracer.
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content: Hope you'll feel better soon!
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content: I had worn a hole through my cap on my tooth! they replaced it this morning. Not your normal checkin but I was quite shocked that it had worn to the extent it had and explains why i was having some sensitivity :joy:
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
Day 16 - Pixel progress :red: :green_large_square: :blue_square:

:checkered_flag: :checkered_flag: I finished weekend raytracing (the first "book") :checkered_flag: :checkered_flag:

I still don't truly grok the math but I had a lot of fun today playing with the final bits of work and rendering the final scene! I am very happy with the performance in Go and now I have a nice toy project to explore the new memory arena experiment with. I made a committment in the live checkin that I will show up with a plan for wave function collapse work in tomorrow's check in... Looks like that will be explored in the morning before checkin :sweat_smile:

Any way - back to rendering - I added intermediate output which is very satisfying to watch the image come to life:

And here is the final image from the tutorial which renders in about ~18 minutes in WSL on a Ryzen 5800:

image.png
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
Day 17 - Lotsa videos and chatting :speaking_head:

No code written today but I did get my tower upgraded to 32gb ram which will be a big help with having all my apps running and a few things cooking in dockerland.

:pear: :pear: Big thank you to @Anonymous User & @Anonymous User for pairing and giving me the explanation on all the vector basics and helping my intuition around what is happening inside my raytracer.

I think tomorrow I am just going to keep watching more on vector things and keep working sample problems and push off the WFC stuff another day or two.
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
Day 18 & 19 - Tired and flailing a bit :face_exhaling:

I didn't post a checkin yesterday so it is getting lumped in with today's. I am feeling a bit inferior and unfocused. (Thank you feelingswheel.com.

Nothing that won't correct itself just wish I had figured out a clearer focus to end the week.

:pear: :pear: :pear: Today, however, was fantastic. I thoroughly enjoyed talking to @Anonymous User @Anonymous User @Anonymous User about python things and I am excited to put together some katas and koans for us to practice next week.

I know lots of folks come here to learn but it has really been amazing to just be here to play and help others grow. Continues to speak to my desires to move past being an IC but wanting to remain in tech.

Can't wait to stream some pairing, somehow, with @Anonymous User monday!

Hope everyone has a delightful weekend!

messages.content:
Day 20 - Stardate 100680.33

:pear: I had so much fun pairing with everyone today! Big thanks to @Anonymous User for helping me learn how to collaboratively stream with Streamlabs Desktop!

This is the start of the final two weeks of my six week batch and I want to both focus and continue to play and explore the things that interest me outside of my normal "job." These final, few days will be spent exploring more graphics, proceedurally generating things (will at least complete one WFC tutorial) and have something playable along the likes of the 7DRL challenge[0] (I would be doing the "out of challenge" variant). Unsure if I will do some more graphics specific work on the raytracer or move on to other small experiments in Go.

7DRL Challenges are NOT about being a fast coder, but rather proving you can release a finished, playable roguelike to the world. There is no winner of the challenge, but rather all those who finish are honoured for their work, the criterion is completeness.

[0] https://7drl.com/

messages.content:
Day 21 & 22 - Moar podcasting and game planning :studio_microphone:

I went to bed at 8pm yesterday and missed my evening checkin post so I am doing yesterday and today in this post.

Episode 2 of the podcast is out! https://leetrout.com/fishtales/e2/

:sunflower: Gratitudes

  • @Anonymous User for the rubber ducking
  • @Anonymous User for the delightful coffee chat
  • @Anonymous User for pairing :pear:
  • @Anonymous User for chatting with me about games and game mechanics

BIG thank you to @Anonymous User for being there for me and helping me realize avenues for personal growth (and the games chat, too).

I was inspired to think about what I want to accomplish with my 7DRL challenge and the chat yesterday reinforced my belief I should probably just use Godot.

If I don't use Godot these are the Go-based engines I am considering (in order of popularity):

  • https://ebitengine.org/
    • https://github.com/hajimehoshi/ebiten
  • https://github.com/faiface/pixel
  • https://github.com/oakmound/oak
  • https://github.com/JoelOtter/termloop
  • https://www.raylib.com/
    • https://github.com/gen2brain/raylib-go

For those that don't know there are mountains of free game resources and one of the best is Kenney which I plan to use if I can:

  • https://www.kenney.nl/

I have been doodling game mechanics on the whiteboard and I am thinking with the firefighter theme it might be neat to try to make it realistic and you have a fixed length of hose which will limit your move amount and require you to exit and re-enter the building to extend when you realize you are out of movement with the current length.

This seems like a good way for me to engage with various pathfinding algorithms in a unique way that's not just enemy movement.

I am attracted to falling sand games like sandspiel and Noita (and I have played a bit of noita since it has a combustion mechanic) but I don't think I want to do a side scroller so I've been wondering what this would be like if it were top down or isometric with multiple layers. I am clearly distracted with the graphics and need to just start writing code and moving on :wink:

Y'all are the best! Happy Wednesday :arabian_camel:
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content: Movement is typically very important in roguelikes. They are all about carefully using your turns to confront enemies at the right time. I love your hose idea because it would be a very neat innovation on that theme!
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content: @Anonymous User do you have some time to chat today? you have great ideas and insight and I work better when I can riff with someone.

messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
Day 23 - Lots of pears :pear:

I didn't feel well this morning so got a late start. Short update here - spent the entire day on video with various folks and managed to squeeze in a quick stream tonight trying to figure out how to co-stream with desktop views on twitch.

I am pretty pumped to see everyone learning so much stuff. I had fun playing with p5.js and I see why so many folks use it. It was fun to just open a browser and make something!

Big thank you to @Anonymous User for investing time with me today on my game ideas!

Decisions made:

  • :check: Use godot
  • :check: Use asset pack
  • :check: plan of attack
    • 2 days ramping back up on godot and a top down tile set
      • playable sample level
    • ~2 days on path finding and restricting
      • sample level has fire hose
    • ~3 days on wave function collapse generation
    • <1 day to polish a bit

:firefighter:
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
where does one find asset packs?
it seems like next week could be a natural game jam time ...
also i downloaded streamlabs today after talking to cindy. i'm psyched to do my first stream!
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
Michael Nagle (he/they) (F2'22) said:

where does one find asset packs?
it seems like next week could be a natural game jam time ...
also i downloaded streamlabs today after talking to cindy. i'm psyched to do my first stream!

I am going to use https://www.kenney.nl/

You can find more on https://itch.io/game-assets and free ones at https://itch.io/game-assets/free

@Anonymous User @Anonymous User I will pay for streamlabs ultra to be able to do a group stream with all of us. Are y'all interested?
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
oh for sure!
i wondered if group stream is necesarry or if we can just hop on a discord or zoom call?
but i am down to try things!
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
Depends on what you want to accomplish .... there's no wrong way to eat a reese's

The quality and latency is better when you have direct connections vs streaming a view of discord or zoom and rebroadcasting that but it doesn't make a huge difference if you don't need to switch between various layouts and still want control of camera placement
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
@Anonymous User @Anonymous User I will pay for streamlabs ultra to be able to do a group stream with all of us. Are y'all interested?

YES
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
Day 24 + weekend: Waiting for Godot

I didn't post an update on Friday so this update covers Friday through the weekend with updates from Day 23

4 working days remaining

Last week is here and I want to finish strong. Lots to look forward to and already feeling sad about having to figure out how to return to "the real world".

:sunflower: Gratitudes

  • thank you @Anonymous User for the refresher on vectors / matricies as that is continuing to pay dividends
  • thank you @Anonymous User for continuing to ping me on django things . Especially appreciate the ability to learn where my assumptions fail or my advice was misleading!
  • thank you @Anonymous User for letting me ramble about decomposing projects and chatting django things
  • thank you @Anonymous User in advance for helping me ship something with Godot this week :sunglasses:

Timeline update:

  • 2 days getting reacquainted with Godot (spent)
    • lotsa tutorials. lotsa vectors and they make a ton more sense after having done the raytracer
    • playable sample level does not exist
    • did generate a maze from a tutorial
  • 2 days on path finding and restricting (happening)
    • understand more about appropriate ways to split concerns for pathfinding in godot
      • not unlike MVC - separate look / feel (animation) [sprite] from movement control [map]
  • Will start on WFC tomorrow no matter what I finish today so I continue to get more breadth.

image.png

messages.content:
Day 25 - There's no business like... no business

Nothing to report from Monday 2/6. I played with Godot but have not figured out all the movement mechanics. Partially from stalling because I am spending more time with the engine's UX instead of just bush whacking through to make something functional. I did make it to the graphics book club meeting and I acquired the book. Looking forward to participating as an alum!

Realistically I won't get a ton of stuff accomplished today due to coffee chats and pairing. This is what I am RC for and would much rather do that than just sit here working alone which I can do any time. :smile:
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
Day 26 & 27 .... bankruptcy!

https://media2.giphy.com/media/VeqoDqdvj2J7bNVJFq/giphy.gif?cid=c623cb3574fmjzswuklmb9snj7fz3omlxgsci229l12ra5j2&rid=giphy.gif&ct=g

I am declaring bankruptcy on the Roguelike game. I have thoroughtly enjoyed researching games and learning Godot. Importantly I am not going to give up on the idea but there is just way too much to learn and do to accomplish what I want to do and there is no way it's gonna happen tomorrow which ends my seven days for the roguelike challenge (7DRL).

@Anonymous User some interesting games loosely related to the concepts of view management we discussed.

  • https://managore.itch.io/sandstorm
  • https://managore.itch.io/roguelight

So two days left and I am not going to make any commitments on project deliverables. I'll keep plugging away on some Godot things and try to finish the WFC tutorial.
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content: Roguelight looks awesome!
messages.subject: Lee Trout

messages.content:
Days 28 & 29 - The End(ish) :end:

Lots of chats the past couple days in lieu of coding on my own projects. I feel I must reiterate: this is where I have found tremendous value in RC. Thank you everyone for all the talking and listening! You'll always be able to find me in #consciousness > Lee :octopus:

Of course I knew on the first day there would be a last day but it arrived much quicker than I expected. RC was everything I expected and more. There is something special here and I am very happy to have been able to participate remotely. It was great to meet so many wonderful people and learn about all the varied interests and topics!

I applied to RC not knowing what to expect. I had an absolute blast working on the programming challenge (I did the space invaders clone) but I could still feel the twinges of burnout in October. It's still there but nothing like it was so many months ago. The people, the ideas, and the conversations here all contributed to reminding me why I got into tech and how much fun can be had at all levels of the stack and at all stages in our journey to master the technical interests we have.

I leave energized, refreshed and excited to make another go at my career in the same stage I left instead of abandoning it. I'm not sure what will come of it but this experience has solidified my desire to lead, teach, coach and mentor more than just sling code. I hope folks like me continue to get the opportunity to participate in this program and they are as welcome as I have been to be more on the fringe of programming than breathing and living it every minute of every day.

I cannot say thank you enough! I am excited to stay involved as an alum and look forward to the next chapter!

Until later... it's now! :wink:

Lee

PS I moved my desk to the cookery. There are plenty of seats around the table if anyone would like to join me :cook: :sunglasses:

Recap by week

  • 1
    • Lots of socializing
    • Launched new personal site with Hugo, Tailwind & Alpine JS
    • Started figuring out more about streaming
  • 2
    • Rendered a donut in my terminal with SDF
    • Learned all about DaVinici Resolve
  • 3
    • Learned about WAV files and driving animation with them
    • Started the ray tracer
  • 4
    • Finished the ray tracer
    • Flailed with math concepts trying to cement understanding of the SDF donut and the ray tracer
  • 5
    • Explored Godot game engine and various game concepts
    • Started the 7DRL: 7 day roguelike challenge (no clue what I was doing)
  • 6
    • Declared bankruptcy on the 7DRL challenge :see_no_evil:
    • Lots of socializing and think about the future
    • More play with technology with no pressure / deliverable
      • Godot (really fell in love with it, reminds me of missing flash)
      • Figma plugins API
      • Terraform visual editor concepts (which led to conversations that turned me on to System Initiative)
